Parhyale hawaiensis is a species of amphipod crustacean, commonly known as the Hawaiian sand flea or Hawaiian beach hopper. It is a small, laterally compressed organism that inhabits sandy and rocky beaches in coastal regions of the Hawaiian Islands.

This species is characterized by its ability to jump and hop rapidly across the surface of the sand or substrate, which it uses to evade predators and move across its habitat. Parhyale hawaiensis has a pair of large, prominent antennae and a segmented body with seven pairs of legs. The species exhibits sexual dimorphism, with males often being larger and having more prominent appendages than females.

Parhyale hawaiensis is an important component of the beach ecosystem, serving as a key food source for various predators, such as shorebirds and larger crustaceans. It plays a crucial role in the decomposition and nutrient cycling of organic matter on the beach, contributing to the overall health and productivity of the coastal environment.

The species has been widely studied in the field of developmental biology and evolutionary biology, as it has become a model organism for understanding the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying crustacean development and adaptation to the marine environment.
